slide.title: Peri/Pancreatic fluid collection
slide.notes: Look at The cect, … however in practice: some cases are overlapping
slide.notesNormalized: look at the cect, … however in practice: some cases are overlapping
slide.notesHtml: Look at The cect, … however in practice: some cases are overlapping
slide.text:
4 week later Well defined wall (completely encapsulated) Heterogeneous(some may homogeneous) liquid & solid density with varying degrees of loculations. Intra or peripancreatic location Well circumscribed & capsulated Homogeneous fluid density No non-liquid component Intra or peripancreatic location No definable wall encapsulating Homogeneous fluid density No non-liquid component Intra or peripancreatic location
No definable wall encapsulating the collection Heterogeneous non-liquid density with varying degrees of loculations. Intra or peripancreatic location, ANC APFC WON PPS Bank PA, et al. Gut 2013;62:102-111 Imaging Definition: Peri/Pancreatic fluid collection Endoscopic drainage

PFC: Metal stent vs Plastic stent Metal stent (LAMS) Plastic stent Diameter Large hole Small hole Resolution Quicker Slower Necrosectomy Easily Difficult
Technique One step, may Multi-step, always Fluoroscope Not required, may Need Adverse events ? ? Cost/stent More Less
2 Stent type: Property
2017 2018 2019 Two-arm comparison

slide.title: A systematic review and meta-analysis
slide.text: Bapaye A, et al. WON: NAGI vs Plastic. Dig Endosc 2017;29:104-10 Mukai S, et al.WON: Mixed Metal vs Plastic Endoscopy 2015;47:47-55. Lakhtakia S, et al. WON: NAGI GIE 2017;85:1243-52. Law ST, et al. WON: LAMS vs tubular Surg Endosc 2018;32:2448-53 Rinninella E, et al. PFC: AXIOS GIE 2015;82:1039-46. Sharaiha RZ, et al. WON: LAMS Clin Gastroenterol Hepatol 2016;14:1797-803. Siddiqui AA, et al. PFC: LAMS GIE 2016;83:699-707. Walter D, et al. PFC: LAMS Endoscopy 2015;47:63-7 Siddiqui AA, et al. WON: Tubular vs LAMS vs Plastic GIE 2017;85:758-65. Rana SS, et al. WON: Endosc Ultrasound 2014;3:118-22. Siddiqui AA, et al. WON: Tubular vs LAMS vs Plastic GIE 2017;85:758-65. Schmidt PN, et al. WON: Scand J Gastroenterol 2015;50:611-8. Thompson CC, et al. WON: Pancreatology 2016;16:66-72 Panwar R, Singh PM. Clin J Gastroenterol 2017;10:403-414 A systematic review and meta-analysis 2014-2016 6 studies for 856 patients: Metal stent 479 patients and Plastic stent 377 patients Metal (%) Plastic (%) MH-OR p Sharaiha RZ, et al. PPS: Tubular vs Plastic GIE 2015;82:822-827 Bang JY, et al. PFC: Hot AXIOS vs Plastic Dig Endosc 2017;29:83-90 Lee BU, et al. PPS: Tubular vs Plastic Endoscopy 2014;46:1078-1084 Abu Dayyeh BK, et al. WON: Axios vs Plastic GIE2017; Ang TL, et al. PFC: NAGI vs Plastic Endosc Ultrasound 2016;5:320-327 Two-arm comparative studies, Only 1 RCT, 5 Retro PFC: 3 for WON, 2 for PPS, 1 for PFC 1 Siddiqui AA, et al. WON: Tubular vs LAMS vs Plastic GIE 2017;85:758-65. Clinical success 94.55 (95%CI 92.13-96.25) 85.03 (95%CI 81.06-88.29) 3.22 (95%CI 1.87-5.54) <0.001 (Significant in WON more than in PPS) Adverse events 16.28 (95%CI 13.25-19.86) 29.71 (95%CI 25.32-34.51) 0.40 (95%CI 0.24-0.65) Infection 8.93 (95%CI 6.65-11.89) 18.40 (95%CI 14.62-22.88) 0.37 (95%CI 0.23-0.57) Salvage procedure 3.76 (95%CI 2.39-5.86) 10.61 (95%CI 7.89-14.13) 2017 Recurrence: NS

slide.title: Meta-analysis
slide.text: Bapaye A, et al. WON: NAGI vs Plastic. Dig Endosc 2017;29:104-10 Lakhtakia S, et al. WON: NAGI GIE 2017;85:1243-52. Law ST, et al. WON: LAMS vs tubular Surg Endosc 2018;32:2448-53 Rinninella E, et al. PFC: AXIOS GIE 2015;82:1039-46. Sharaiha RZ, et al. WON: LAMS Clin Gastroenterol Hepatol 2016;14:1797-803. Siddiqui AA, et al. PFC: LAMS GIE 2016;83:699-707. Walter D, et al. PFC: LAMS Endoscopy 2015;47:63-7 Siddiqui AA, et al. WON: Tubular vs LAMS vs Plastic GIE 2017;85:758-65. Rana SS, et al. WON: Endosc Ultrasound 2014;3:118-22. Siddiqui AA, et al. WON: Tubular vs LAMS vs Plastic GIE 2017;85:758-65. Schmidt PN, et al. WON: Scand J Gastroenterol 2015;50:611-8. Thompson CC, et al. WON: Pancreatology 2016;16:66-72 Yoon SB, Lee IS, Choi M-G.UEG Journal 2018;6:729-738 Meta-analysis 2014-2017 7 studies for 905 patients: Metal stent 495 patients and Plastic stent 410 patients Metal (%) Plastic (%) OR p Technical success 99.2 97.6 2.81 (95%CI 0.69-11.35) 0.294 Clinical success 94.1 82.6 3.39 (95%CI 2.05-5.6) 0.489 Adverse events 16.0 29.7 0.37 (95%CI 0.21-0.66) 0.091 Bleeding and stent migration: NS OR 0.53 (95%CI 0.24-1.18)/0.60 (95%CI 0.28-1.29) Re-intervention 12.4 26.7 0.54 (95%CI 0.22-1.29) 0.165 Recurrence OR 0.65 (95%CI 0.06-6.70) Sharaiha RZ, et al. PPS: Tubular vs Plastic GIE 2015;82:822-827 Bang JY, et al. PFC: Hot AXIOS vs Plastic Dig Endosc 2017;29:83-90 Lee BU, et al. PPS: Tubular vs Plastic Endoscopy 2014;46:1078-1084 Abu Dayyeh BK, et al. WON: Axios vs Plastic GIE2017; Ang TL, et al. PFC: NAGI vs Plastic Endosc Ultrasound 2016;5:320-327 Two-arm comparative studies, Only 1 RCT, 6 Retro PFC: 3 for WON, 2 for PPS, 2 for PFC Siddiqui AA, et al. WON: Tubular vs LAMS vs Plastic GIE 2017;85:758-65. 2 2018 Procedure time: Shorter in Metal gr. (3 studies) Mukai S, et al.WON: Mixed Metal vs Plastic Endoscopy 2015;47:47-55.

slide.title: A systematic review and meta-analysis
slide.text: Bapaye A, et al. WON: NAGI vs Plastic. Dig Endosc 2017;29:104-10 Mukai S, et al.WON: Mixed Metal vs Plastic Endoscopy 2015;47:47-55. Lakhtakia S, et al. WON: NAGI GIE 2017;85:1243-52. Law ST, et al. WON: LAMS vs tubular Surg Endosc 2018;32:2448-53 Rinninella E, et al. PFC: AXIOS GIE 2015;82:1039-46. Sharaiha RZ, et al. WON: LAMS Clin Gastroenterol Hepatol 2016;14:1797-803. Siddiqui AA, et al. PFC: LAMS GIE 2016;83:699-707. Walter D, et al. PFC: LAMS Endoscopy 2015;47:63-7 Siddiqui AA, et al. WON: Tubular vs LAMS vs Plastic GIE 2017;85:758-65. Rana SS, et al. WON: Endosc Ultrasound 2014;3:118-22. Siddiqui AA, et al. WON: Tubular vs LAMS vs Plastic GIE 2017;85:758-65. Schmidt PN, et al. WON: Scand J Gastroenterol 2015;50:611-8. Thompson CC, et al. WON: Pancreatology 2016;16:66-72 Saunder R, et al. Surgical Endoscopy 2019;33:1412-1425 A systematic review and meta-analysis 2014-2017 7 studies for 681 patients: Metal stent 340 patients and Plastic stent 341 patients Metal (%) Plastic (%) RR p Clinical success 93.8 86.2 1.08 (95%CI1.02-1.14) 0.009 Adverse events 10.2 25.0 0.42 (95%CI 0.22-0.81) 0.010 Bleeding 2.8 7.9 0.37 (95%CI0.18-0.75) 0.006 Infection 5.4 13.2 0.53 (95%CI 0.23-1.20) 0.127 Re-intervention 12.4 26.7 0.54 (95%CI 0.22-1.29) 0.165 Sharaiha RZ, et al. PPS: Tubular vs Plastic GIE 2015;82:822-827 Bang JY, et al. PFC: Hot AXIOS vs Plastic Dig Endosc 2017;29:83-90 Lee BU, et al. PFC: Tubular vs Plastic Endoscopy 2014;46:1078-1084 Abu Dayyeh BK, et al. WON: Axios vs Plastic GIE2017; Ang TL, et al. PFC: NAGI vs Plastic Endosc Ultrasound 2016;5:320-327 Two-arm comparative studies, Only 1 RCT, 6 Retro PFC: 3 for WON, 1 for PPS, 3 for PFC 3 2019 Siddiqui AA, et al. WON: Tubular vs LAMS vs Plastic GIE 2017;85:758-65.

slide.title: Pseudocyst/WON drainage: Metal
slide.text: More clinical success (WON/PPS) Tend to less adverse events (PPS) Short procedure time Tend to less reintervention/salvage procedure Pseudocyst/WON drainage: Metal Bleeding Infection Stent migration

Assessed for eligibility (n=80) Feb2016-March 2017 Excluded (n=20) Won not seen on EUS (5) Cystic lesion on EUS (1) WON too small (6) Acute necrotic collection (6) No safe window for endoscopic drainage (2) Randomized (n=60) LAMS (n=31) Plastic (n=29) Treatment success 93.5% Resolution of OF/SIRS (>24hr) 50%/44.4% No of procedure for treatment success 2.8(1.2) 2 (median), 1 (IQR), 2-7 (range) Adverse events 41.9% stent related 32.3% (embedded gastric wall 2, bleeding 3, biliary stricture 3, buried stent 2) clinical 9.7% Procedure duration 15 min Hospital stay, mean (SD) 6.2(9.0), No of readmission 32.2% Recurrent WON 3.2% COST total*/procedure 53117/12155 GUT 2019;68:1200-1209 F/U minimum 6 m 29% SIRS 40% degree of necrosis 9.7% multigate technique 2.8 procedure for success Additional procedure after 72 hr 2-transmural 4-necrosectomy 2-percutaneous Treatment success 96.6% p 0.999 Resolution of OF/SIRS (>24hr) 25%/69.2% p0.999/0.384 No of procedure for treatment success 3.2(1.5) p 0.192 (mean (SD) 3 (median), 2 (IQR), 2-7 (range) Adverse events 20.7% p 0.077 stent related 6.9% p 0.014
clinical 13.8% p 0.702 Procedure duration 40 min p<0.001 Hospital stay 12.2(21.1) p 0.129 No of readmission 35.4% p 0.645 Recurrent WON 0% p 0.999 COST 50132/6609 p 0.775 * Total cost: hospital stay, procedure, pharmacy, radiology, anesthesia, Laboratory and other support services 44.8% SIRS 45.3% degree of necrosis 31.0% multigate technique 3.2 procedure for success Additional procedure after 72 hr 5-transmural 6-necrosectomy 5-percutaneous

slide.title: LAMS: Avoid complication!
slide.text: Bang JY, et al. Gut 2016;66:2054-2056 LAMS: Avoid complication! Safety Zone

slide.title: Factor prediction in needed necrosectomy
slide.notes: Not only clinical parameter, but also morphologic feature of solid component
slide.notesNormalized: not only clinical parameter, but also morphologic feature of solid component
slide.notesHtml: Not only clinical parameter, but also morphologic feature of solid component
slide.text:
Factor prediction in needed necrosectomy Rena SS, Bhasin DK, Sharma RK, et al. Endosc Ultrasound 2014;3: 40% of solid debris ( by EUS) : need direct endoscopic/surgical necrosectomy Necrosis of >50% (by CECT) 12 vs 26 p 0.011
Cao XI, Cao F , Li A, et al. Experimental and Therapeutic Medicine 2017;14: 4397-4404 PCD alone vs PCD (N-32)/Necrosectomy (N-42)
MCTSI 6.0±1.48 vs 7.3±1.87 p 0.020, Multiple organ 6 (18.7) vs 24 (57.1) p 0.001 Ji L, Wang G, Li L, et al. Pancreas.2018 Apr;47(4):436-443. (CT) density of necrotic fluid collection (NFC; P < 0.001), Multiple-organ failure (MOF; P < 0.001) within 24 hours before the initial PCD Serum procalcitonin level (P = 0.035) 3 days after the initial PCD % of necrosis detected in the previous CT scan (47 ± 20% vs. 15 ± 18%, p = 0,008) Purulent aspect of the fluid drained (100% vs. 40%; p = 0,044) predicted the need for necrosectomy in the univariable analysis, but only the first in the multivariable (p = 0,042) Gonzalez L, Brujats A, Trias M, et al. ESGE Days 2019 (ePoster) Morphologic Clinical Biochemical

slide.title: Choice of stent: PFCs Drainage
slide.text: Plastic versus Metal stent placement: Retro 49 patients, PC 31-WON18 37:plastic vs 12: FCMS CSEMS Plastic p Technical success 100% 100% Clinical success 91.7% 64.9% P 0.074 (initial) 100% 94.6% p 0.411 (final) Repeat drainage 6.3% 34.2% p 0.032 Stent migration 7.1% 18.4% P 0.043 COST Choice of stent: PFCs Drainage Ang TL, et al. PFC: NAGI vs Plastic Endosc Ultrasound 2016;5:320-327 All PC $4340 $5164 (P = 0.009) infected PC only $4816 $5554 (P = 0.575) PC with mass effect only $4182 $5190 (P = 0.038) PFC needing DEN $7362 $6916 (P = 0.760)

slide.title: Summary in Metal stent placement in symptomatic PFC
slide.titleNormalized: summary in metal stent placement in symptomatic pfc
slide.text:
Summary in Metal stent placement in symptomatic PFC PPS if rapid resolution is needed.
WON if necrosectomy is needed.
If Fluoroscopy in not available, cautery-tip LAMS is recommended. Favor Metal stent but cost (LAMS) is to be concerned in PPS

slide.title: Thank you very much for your kind attention
slide.titleNormalized: thank you very much for your kind attention
slide.text: Thank you very much for your kind attention
